body_text.text: Banana is the second ranking fruit crop in the world, with an annual world production of ;70 million metric tons (FAOstat, 2007 faostat.fao.org/site/567/DesktopDefault. aspx?).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Banana fruit ripening is characterized by a burst of ethylene production and respiration concomitantly with physicochemical and biochemical changes, including chlorophyll breakdown, increased starch degradation and sugar synthesis, and fruit softening.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Finger drop is one of the main features closely associated with the banana ripening process.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This process, which was reported for the first time in the triploid Cavendish AAA group, involves physiological softening and weakening, thus causing individual fruit in a hand to separate from the crown (Hicks, 1934;Baldry et al., 1981;Semple and Thompson 1988).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Bananas are marketed in hands of generally 4-9 fruits.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Dislodgement of individual fruits from the hand considerably reduces the commercial value of the product because hands with fingers missing or fingers without pedicels cannot be sold to consumers.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The finger drop process thus reduces the economic value of bananas.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Despite this important economic impact, few studies have been devoted to gaining an insight into the physiological mechanisms related to banana finger drop.
body_text.section: Introduction

ref_spans.text: (Nishitani, 1997; Campbell and Braam, 1999; Rose et al., 2002; Saladié et al., 2006)

body_text.text: Susceptibility to finger drop varies widely according to cultivars and their ripening conditions, with triploid cultivars being less susceptible than tetraploids (New and Marriot, 1983).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Among triploid cultivars, Valery is less susceptible than Gros Michel, and Hom Tong (Musa acuminata, AAA) shows massive drop while Namwa (Musa sp., ABB) does not (New and Marriot, 1983;Saengpook et al., 2007). In addition to cultivars, the level of fruit development ripening conditions (including ethylene, humidity, and temperature) also affect the susceptibility to banana finger drop (Semple and Thompson, 1988;Paull, 1996;Imsabai et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Studies on the physiological mechanisms of banana finger drop have only recently been carried out and, to our knowledge, performed only at the biochemical level.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In a study on two varieties that display massive (Hom Tong variety) and no finger drop (Namwa variety), respectively, Imsabai et al. (2006) showed that peel water content and thickness did not affect the finger drop process.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: By contrast, differential changes in the water-and CDTA-soluble fractions, and in the insoluble pectin fraction at the peel rupture area in the Hom Tong variety indicated high pectin breakdown and degradation activity in this variety.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The authors also showed that this pectin breakdown was mainly the result of pectate lyase and polygalacturonase enzymes, as their corresponding activities increased concomitantly in the peel rupture area of the Hom Tong variety as compared with those of the Namwa variety.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is now assumed that cell wall modifications that occur during fruit ripening correspond to a complex process involving different mechanisms, including enzymatic and non-enzymatic degradation of cell wall components (Dumville and Fry, 2003;Bennett and Labavitch, 2008), cell wall synthesis (Mitcham et al., 1989(Mitcham et al., , 1991Greve and Labavitch, 1991;Huysamer et al., 1997;Rose and Bennett, 1999) and/or loosening of the cell wall network mediated by non-enzymatic proteins like expansin (Brummell, 2006).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Enzymatic degradation of cell wall components is the result of the induction, at both molecular and biochemical levels, of pectolic and/or non-pectolitic cell wall-modifying proteins (CWMPs) according to the specific class of polysaccharides used as substrate.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The pectolytic enzymes include endo-and exo-polygalacturonases (endo-EC 3.2.1.15; exo-EC 3.2.1.67), pectate lyases (PEL; EC 4.2. 2.2), pectin methylesterases (PME; EC 3.1.1.11), pectin acetylesterases (PAE; EC 3.1.1.-), b-galactosidases (EC 3.2. 1.23), and a-L-arabinofuranosidases (EC 3.2.1.55) (Vicente et al., 2007;Goulao and Oliveira, 2008).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These enzymes are able to cleave or modify the nature of the polysaccharide backbone or to remove neutral sugars from branched side-chains.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Non-pectolytic enzymes are responsible for hemicellulose modifications and include endo-1,4-bglucanases (EGase; EC 3.2.1.4), endo-1,4-b-xylanases (EC 3.2.1.8), b-xylanases (EC 3.2.1.37), and xyloglucan endotransglycosylase/hydrolases (XTH; EC 2.4.1.207).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Many of these proteins have been investigated, at both molecular and biochemical levels, in relationship with banana fruit softening.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A co-ordinated increase in mRNA abundance, de novo synthesis or activity of a number of putative cell wallmodifying enzymes that may be responsible for or contribute significantly to polymer modifications has been observed (Dominguez-Puigjaner et al., 1997;Pua et al., 2001;Marin-Rodriguez et al., 2003;Trivedi and Nath, 2004;Asif and Nath, 2005;Zhuang et al., 2006Zhuang et al., , 2007Sane et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As none of these genes have been examined in relation to finger drop, an attempt was made to investigate, at the molecular level, the putative relationship between the expression of some cell wall-modifying genes (CWMGs) and the finger drop process in order to identify:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (i) the putative physiological mechanism of the cell wall metabolism involved in the finger drop process, and
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (ii) relevant genes involved for purposes of identification of functional molecular markers.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Banana is a complex species and attempts to improve the fruit quality through breeding strategies is complex and difficult to set up.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Access to functional molecular markers derived from relevant genes associated with fruit quality traits should therefore provide a valuable and helpful resource for the development of new crossing strategies and the selection process.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, gaining further insight into the molecular mechanisms that govern the elaboration of fruit quality traits and their regulation is a key prerequisite for the development of other strategies to improve banana quality traits like post-harvest technology and/or biotechnology approaches.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the present study, the accumulation of mRNA genes encoding a broad array of enzymes known to hydrolyse or modify the fine structure of cell wall polysaccharides was examined, with the view of correlating particular mechanisms and genes with previously observed changes in cell wall composition during finger drop.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: All tissues used in this study were harvested from three banana plants (Musa acuminata, AAA, Cavendish, cv. Grande Naine) grown at the CIRAD research station (elevation: 250 m; andosol; rainfall: 3500 mm year À1 ), Guadeloupe (French West Indies).
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: During growth, bunches on banana plants were covered with blue plastic bags to hamper insect infestations, and to streamline the development of whole fruits on the bunch.
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: Green fruits were harvested at commercial ripeness, as determined on the basis of the heat unit concept (Ganry and Meyer, 1975;Jullien et al., 2008).
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: At each harvesting time, only internal fingers of the median hand on the bunch, considered as comparable (Liu, 1976), were taken into account for each bunch.
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: After harvest, all fruits were kept for 24 h at 20°C in chambers ventilated with humidified air before treatment with 10 000 ppm of azethyl (95% nitrogen/5% ethylene) for 24 h at 20°C and ambient humidity.
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: From 1-7 d after treatment (DAT), a sample of three fruits was taken daily for finger drop measurement.
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: Immediately at the end of each measurement, peel tissues corresponding to the median part of the fruit (control zone) and to the rupture area of the fruit pedicel (drop zone) ( Fig. 1) were sampled, separately frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at -80°C until use.
body_text.section: Plant material

body_text.text: Finger drop was estimated by measuring the pedicel rupture force using a TA-XT2 penetrometer and an adapted probe as follows.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Banana fruit were attached 6 cm above a table with a large clip.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The probe was pressed down to a depth of 40 mm and at a constant speed of 5 mm s À1 , at the pedicel until it separated from the fruit (Chillet et al., 2008).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The required force was expressed in Newtons (N).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: All of these measurements were performed in triplicate on three separate fruits and the experiment was repeat three times.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Isolation of banana fruit genes coding for xyloglucan endotransglycosylase/hydrolase-like (XTH-like) and pectin methylesterase-like (PME-like)
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Partial cDNAs encoding banana XTH-like genes were amplified using the 3# RACE-PCR method (Frohman, 1990).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Total RNA was extracted separately from peel tissue from control and drop zones of banana fruit taken at commercial ripeness, and at 1-4 DAT, using the modified hot-borate method (Wan and Wilkins, 1994;Mbéguié-A-Mbéguié et al., 2008a).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: According to the manufacturer's instructions, 2 lg of each RNA extract was DNAse-treated using RQI DNase (Promega, Charbonières, France) before being separately reverse-transcribed into cDNA using Oligo-dT 17 primers (Frohman, 1990; see Supplementary Table S1 at JXB online) and AMV reverse transcriptase enzyme (Promega).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: These cDNA were pooled and 1 ll of this mixture was subjected to 3# RACE-PCR with Xth-F1 and dT 17 -adapter primers in a 25 ll reaction containing 13 Taq buffer (Eurobio, Courtaboeuf, France), 150 nM of dNTP, 1.5 mM of MgCl 2 , 200 nM of each primer, and 1 U of Taq polymerase.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Xth-F1 is a degenerated forward primer designed from a conserved HDE(I/M)DFEF region among plant XTH-like proteins ( Table 1).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The PCR program involved one cycle of 1 min at 94°C for template denaturation and Taq activation followed by 40 cycles of 30 s at 94°C for template denaturation, 1 min at 40°C for primer annealing, and 2 min at 72°C for template elongation.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The isolated cDNA fragments (approximately 1100 bp) were cloned into pGEM-T vector using the pGEM-T Easy Cloning kit (Promega) and sequenced by Cogenics (Grenoble, France).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: GenBank accession numbers are FJ264506 (MaXTH3), FJ264507 (MaXTH4), FJ264508 (MaXTH5), FJ264509 (MaXTH6), FJ264510 (MaXTH7), FJ264511 (MaXTH8), and FJ264512 (MaXTH9).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Fig. 1.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of Cavendish banana through pedicel rupture force measurement.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Banana fruits harvested at the mature green stage were stored overnight at 20°C before treatment with 10 000 ppm of azethyl (5% ethylene+95% nitrogen) for 24 h.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Fruits were further kept at 20°C in air for 7 d to ripen.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Banana finger drop was evaluated on the basis of the pedicel rupture force expressed in Newtons (N).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: This force was measured daily from the harvesting point (Ht) to day 7, as described by Chillet et al. (2008).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Each data point is the mean of values obtained from at least four fruits originating from four replicate bunches.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: Vertical bars indicate standard deviation (SD).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: When no bar is shown, the SD is smaller than the symbol.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: For pectin methylesterase genes, one partial cDNA and two genomic sequences coding for banana PME-like genes were isolated in this study.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The partial cDNA sequence was isolated throughout EST sequencing.
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: PME genomic sequences were identified throughout sequencing and annotation of BAC clones MAC077E20 (accession number AC226050) and MAC088K20 (accession number AC226051), isolated from a Cavendish BAC library (Piffanelli et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Measurement of finger drop variations during post-harvest ripening of fruit

body_text.text: The sequence similarity of the genes isolated in this study was determined using the online BLAST (Altschul et al., 1997) and BLAST 2 sequence (Tatusova and Madden, 1999) programs on the National Center for Biotechnology Information BLAST website (National Library of Medicine, Bethesda, MD).
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: For sequence comparison throughout the BLAST 2 program, two additional parameters were introduced, Qcov and Scov, which allows us to take into account the difference of the length between sequences.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: Query coverage (Qcov) is the ratio of length of the match by length of the query sequence.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: This value indicates the part of the query sequence covered by the alignment.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: Similarly, Subject coverage (Scov) was calculated as the ratio of length of the match by length of the subject or target length, and indicates the part of the subject or target sequence covered by the alignment.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: All sequence alignments and phylogenetic tree construction were performed using the ClustalX algorithm with the Gonnet residue weights (Thompson et al., 1997).
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: For XTHs genes, the pair-wise alignment parameters used included a gap opening penalty of 35 and a gap extension penalty of 0.75.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: For multiple alignments, the gap opening penalty was 15, with a gap extension penalty of 0.3 and the delay divergent sequences was set at 25%.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: The consensus tree was drawn using the TREE VIEW program (Page, 1996).
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: Search motifs in the promoter regions of MA-PME genomic sequences was found by screening the PLACE (Prestridge, 1991; Higo et al., 1999) and PLANT CARE (Lescot et al., 2002) databases.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: In silico prediction of 5#-and 3#-UTR regions of MA-PME genes and prediction of signal peptides were performed using EuGène 3.2 with rice parameters (Foissac et al., 2008) and SignalP 3.0 (Bendtsen et al., 2004) programs, respectively.
body_text.section: Bioinformatic sequence analysis

body_text.text: The oligonucleotide primers used for RT-qPCR analysis were designed using the Primer 3 freeware program (Roten and Skaletsky, 2000) according to the default criteria and the corresponding sequences are described in Supplementary Table S1 at JXB online.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: Except for polygalacturonase genes MaPG3 and MaPG4, whose primers were designed Table 1.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: Sequence analysis and comparison of banana PME genes Analysis of nucleotide and polypeptide sequences of PME genes isolated in this study.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: The features of nucleotide and polypeptide sequences of MaPME1 cDNA and those of the two genomic sequences of MaPME2 and MaPME3 are given in (A).
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: A comparison of nucleotide and polypeptide sequences of MaPME genes (B), including determination of Scov and Qcov values, was performed using BLAST 2 (Tatusova and Madden, 1999 within the divergent coding region, all other primers were designed within the 3#-UTR region.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: The lengths of all PCR products ranged from 125 bp to 247 bp.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: The gene specificity of all primer sets was tested using the following three independent procedures:
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: (i) BLAST searches against Gen-Bank databases were performed for each primer to check that no member of a primer set matched another sequence in the banana genome;
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: (ii) the specificity of PCR amplification was examined by monitoring the dissociation curves during qPCR reactions using the ABI PRISM 7000 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems, Courtaboeuf, France);
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: (iii) individual PCR products were separated on 2% agarose gels and stained with ethidium bromide to examine their size and ensure that a single PCR product was detected for each primer pair, in accordance with the single peak observed in the dissociation curve.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: As for the MaPME2 and MaPME3 genes, the corresponding specific primers were designed based on the 3#-UTR predicted from the corresponding genomic sequence.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: The generated PCR fragment was further cloned and sequenced to confirm that it corresponded to a PME genomic sequence.
body_text.section: Oligonucleotide primers for gene expression through real-time qPCR and end-point PCR analysis

body_text.text: All qPCR experiments were performed on an ABI 7000 sequence detection apparatus (Applied Biosystems, Courtaboeuf, France) using the SYBR Green PCR Master Mix as described by Mbéguié-A-Mbéguié et al. (2008b).
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: Two micrograms of total RNA extracted from different banana fruit tissues and organs treated with RQ1 DNase (Promega, Charbonnières, France) to remove possible contaminating genomic DNA were used.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: First-strand cDNA was synthesized from these RNA using AMV reverse transcriptase enzymes (Promega, Charbonnières, France) and random hexamers according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: To hamper the effect of putative PCR inhibitors that might be present in the reverse transcriptase reaction, as well as pipetting errors, the cDNA was 10-fold diluted with distilled water, and 5 ll of the diluted cDNA was used as a template for qPCR analysis.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: The qPCR program included one cycle of 5 min at 94°C for template denaturation and Taq activation, followed by 40 cycles of 30 s at 94°C for template denaturation, 15 s at 50°C for primer annealing, and 30 s at 72°C for primer elongation.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: Fluorescence was analysed using Sequence Detection Software (Applied Biosystems Courtaboeuf, France).
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: A cycle threshold value (Ct) was calculated from the amplification curves by selecting the optimal DRn (emission of reporter dye over starting background fluorescence) in the exponential portion of the amplification plot.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: The amplification efficiency of all primer sets was determined by qPCR analysis as described previously.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: To this end, we used 6 log of 2-fold serial dilutions made from a pool of cDNA reverse-transcribed from a mixture of RQI DNase-treated mRNA from different banana fruit tissues and organs.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: For each dilution, a qPCR was run in triplicate.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: The efficiency (slope) ranges were 83-100% (3.3-3.7), 87-100% (3.3-3.6), 73.3-77.3% (4.02-4.1), and 72-92% (3.12-4.2) for expansin, pectin methylesterase, polygalacturonase, pectate lyase, and xyloglucan endotransferase/hydrolase genes, respectively.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: They were measured using the Ct slope method (data not shown) and the formula E x ¼10 (-1/slope) -1.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: The relative fold differences in expression of each gene between samples were determined using the 2 ÀDDCt formula (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001).
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: For each gene and sample, a qPCR was performed in triplicate on two independent RNA extracts as described above.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: The MA-ACT gene was used as the internal control to standardize the difference between template amounts and fruit tissues taken at harvest before ripening induction was used as the calibrator.
body_text.section: Real-time qPCR analysis

body_text.text: Finger drop evolution of banana fruit measured via the pedicel rupture force Banana fruits were harvested at commercial harvest grade corresponding to approximately 90 days after flowering (DAF).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: According to the rupture force measurement ( Fig. 1), Cavendish banana finger drop started 1 d after ripening induction and continued progressively throughout the postharvest ripening stage.
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: However, a marked decreased was observed between days 1 to 3 after ripening induction, with more than a 2-fold decrease in the pedicel rupture force.
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: As the pedicel rupture force pattern is considered to be a way of measuring banana finger drop (Saengpook et al., 2007), our data suggest that our experimental conditions led to the development of the finger drop process of Cavendish banana.
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: Seven partial cDNA fragments encoding XTH-like polypeptides were isolated from of banana peel tissue.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: As two banana XTH homologues, MaXET1 and MaXET2, were previously isolated and registered in the GenBank database (Lu et al., 2004), the XTH cDNAs isolated in this study were named MaXTH3 to MaXTH9.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: The sequence homology between MaXTH cDNA ranges from 3.1% to 71% at the nucleotide level and from 12% to 81% at the amino acid level, with MaXTH5 and MaXTH6 being highly homologous pairs.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Compared with MaXET1 and MaXET2 genes, a high homology was observed with MaXTH7 and MaXTH4, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Analysis of the predicted MaXTH polypeptides revealed that they contained a DEIDFEFLG motif conserved within glycosyl hydrolase family 16 (GH16) enzymes and, adjacent to the putative active site, the potential N-linked glycosylation site N-X-S/T motif.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: For MaXTH5 and MaXTH6, this last motif was substituted by the N-V-R motif which is characteristic of group-3 XTHs (Campbell and Braam, 1999;Johanson et al., 2004; see Supplementary Fig. S1 at JXB online).
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: A phylogenetic tree was constructed to investigate the evolutionary relationships of XTHs polypeptides from the partial banana cDNA and those from rice, tomato, and Arabidopsis (Fig. 2).
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Our data showed an organization of XTH proteins into two major clusters (I and II) as observed with rice XTH proteins (Yokoyama et al., 2004), another monocotyledonous species as banana.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: A classification into four XTH families was observed in Arabidopsis, tomato, two dicotyledonous species, and in a broad range of plant species (Nishitani, 1997;Campbell and Braam, 1999;Rose et al., 2002;Saladié et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Compared with this organization, our data indicated that cluster II mainly consisted of XTH proteins of family 2 of dicotyledons together with MaXTH4 and MaXTH9.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Cluster I can be divided into two subclusters.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: The first one included MaXET1 and MaXET2, and MaXTH3, MaXTH5, MaXTH6, MaXTH7, and MaXTH8.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: It mainly consisted of XTH proteins of families 3 and 4 of dicotyledons.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: The second one mainly consisted of XTH proteins of families 1 and 2 of dicotyledons.
body_text.section: Cloning of MaXTH genes from banana fruit and sequence analysis

body_text.text: Three genes encoding a putative banana PME polypeptide have been isolated by Musa sequence data mining.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Musa EST sequences produced one partial cDNA sequence (MaPME1 accession number FJ264505).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: A similarity search in available Musa BAC sequences produced two BAC sequences: MaC077E20 (GenBank accession number AC226050) and MaC088K20 (GenBank accession number AC226051) of 177 729 bp and 152 711 bp, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Automatic and manual annotation of these BACs showed that they contained 26 and 19 predicted genes in addition to 1 and 3 repetitive elements, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The two BACs sequences are schematically shown in Supplementary Fig. S2 at JXB online.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: They are collinear and share an overlapping region of 130 kbp.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Both sequences contained one common identical putative PME gene (MaPME2).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: MaC077E20 contained an additional putative PME gene (MaPME3).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Only the putative complete MaPME2 and MaPME3 genes from BAC MaCO77E20 were subsequently used in this study.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The features of MaPME cDNAs and genomic sequences are described in Table 1A.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The putative promoter regions of both MaPME2 and MaPME3 genes were analysed.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: They contained numerous cis-regulatory sequences that might be involved in tissue-specific or developmentallyregulated gene expression (see Supplementary Table S2 at JXB online).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: A sulphur-responsive element that contains the auxin-response factor (ARF) binding sequence (GAGACA) and the copper/O 2 -reponsive element appeared to be specific to MaPME2 and MaPME3 promoter sequences, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The predicted coding region of MaPME1 cDNA, MaPME2 and MaPME3 genomic sequences were compared at both nucleotide and polypeptide levels (Table 1B).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: MaPME2 and MaPME3 genes shared 7% identity at the nucleotide level, while at the amino acid level, they showed 38% and 56% identity and similarity, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Compared to MaPME1 cDNA, MaPME2 and MaPME3 genomic sequences diverged at the nucleotide level.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Indeed, the high percentage of identity (75%) observed between these sequences is not significant as it was obtained in a short portion of their nucleotide sequence, as shown by the low Scov and Qcov values (less than 10% with MaPME2 and 25% with MaPME3).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: At the polypeptide level, MaPME2 and MaPME3 shared 46% and 60% identity and similarity, respectively, with polypeptides predicted from MaPME1 cDNA.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The predicted polypeptides of the three MaPME genes presented features that are conserved in all PME polypeptides.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Among these, there are the pre-and pro-sequences at the N-terminal extension, and five polypeptide segments that are characteristic of the C-terminal catalytic region, which constitutes the mature PME enzyme: GxYxE, QAVAL, QDTL, DFIFG, LGRPW (Micheli, 2001;Markovic and Janecek, 2004; see Supplementary Fig. S2 at JXB online).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The pre-region or signal peptide required for protein targeting to the endoplasmic reticulum is cleaved in the first step of maturation.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: According to the SignalP 3.0 program (Bendtsen et al., 2004); it was localized between amino acid residues 24-25 and 27-28 for MaPME2 and MaPME3, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Pro-sequence cleavage of the covalently attached mature enzyme may occur in the second step of maturation close to the RR(K)LL(M) motif (Markovic and Janecek, 2004; see Supplementary Fig. S2 at JXB online), thus leading to prosequence lengths of 200 and 217 amino acid residues for MaPME2 and MaPME3, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Based on the Arabidopsis PME sequence analysis, PME genes have been classified into two types: type I and II, having a long N-terminal pro-region and a short or absent pro-region, respectively.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The role of the pro-region is currently unknown (Micheli, 2001;Markovic and Janecek, 2004;Giovane et al., 2004;Pelloux, 2007).
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: The long N-terminal pro-sequence of MaPME2 and MaPME3 predicted polypeptides suggests that both genes belong to type I.
body_text.section: Cloning MaPME genes from banana fruit and sequences analysis

body_text.text: Three classes of pectolytic genes were examined in peel tissue during banana fruit ripening and in relation to finger drop.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Among these, three genes encode pectin methylesterase MaPME1 to MaPME3, four encode polygalacturonase (MaPG1 to MaPG4; Asif and Nath, 2005), two encode pectate lyase (MaPEL1 and MaPEL2; Dominguez-Puigjaner et al., 1997;Pua et al., 2001), and four encode expansin protein (MaEXP1, 2, 4, and 5; Sane et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Gene expression experiments were performed in triplicate on two independent RNA extracts and gave the same results.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Pectolytic genes examined in his study were differentially expressed during ripening and in both the control and drop zones (Fig. 3).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaPEL1 and MaPEL2, and MaPG4 genes were the most expressed genes compared with the others.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Among the three MaPME genes, MaPME1 was the least expressed in peel tissue compared with the other two.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Its expression decreased during ripening in both zones (Fig. 3A).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: By contrast, MaPME2 was the most expressed in the drop zone.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the control zone, its mRNA level remained Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Phylogenetic alignment of banana, tomato, Arabidopsis, and rice xyloglucan endotransglycosylase/hydrolases (XTHs).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The regions in common between the XTH polypeptide sequences of banana (MaXTHn and MaXETn), tomato (SlXTHn), Arabidopsis (AtXTHn), and rice were used to contruct a phylogenetic tree using the ClustalX program.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The resulting slanted cladogram was visualized with the TREEVIEW program (Page, 1996).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The sequences were grouped into two distinct groups (I-II).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The numbers 1 to 4 indicate the four families groups identified in tomato and Arabidopsis and applied to a broad range of plant species (Nishitani, 1997; Campbell and Braam, 1999; Rose et al., 2002; Saladié et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The tomato and Arabidopsis thaliana XTH sequences used in this study are available online at http://labs.plantbio.cornell.edu/XTH/genes.htm.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The rice XTHs were retrieved from the Rice genome research program, and polygalacturonase (C) in peel tissue sampled from the middle area (control zone) and rupture area (drop zone).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The y-axis represents the relative fold difference in mRNA level and was calculated using the 2 -DDCt formula (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001) with actin as reference.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: From day 1 to day 7 after ripening induction, both MaPEL1 and MaPEL2 mRNA levels increased drastically and continuously in the control zone (Fig. 3B).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: One day after ripening induction, MaPEL1 and MaPEL2 mRNA were 2-fold more expressed in the drop zone than in the control zone.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The time-course of both MaPEL1 and MaPEL2 mRNA presented a transient decrease (4-fold) in the drop zone at day 2 after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Thereafter, transcripts of both MaPEL genes increased to reach a level comparable with that of the control zone at day 3 for MaPEL2 and 4 for MaPEL1, respectively.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Concerning polygalacturonase genes, the four cDNAs previously isolated in banana present, at nucleotide level, a high percentage of identity.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaPG1 and MaPG2 were 98% identical, although MaPG1 has an additional 160 bp.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaPG3 and MaPG4 were over 90% identical while MaPG2 and MaPG3 were only 30% identical (Asif and Nath, 2005).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Despite this, a set of qPCR primers was designed, as specific as possible, for each MaPG gene.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: For MaPG1 that spans the entire MaPG2 cDNA, primers were designed within the additional 160 bp in the 3#-UTR.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: For MaPG2, there was a failure to identify a divergent region with MaPG1 to design a specific MaPG2 primer.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Nevertheless, MaPG1 and MaPG2 displayed quite different accumulation patterns, suggesting that putative cross amplification of the MaPG1 gene with the MaPG2 primer set would not have interfered during the gene expression analysis.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: No marked changes were observed on MaPG1 gene expression during fruit ripening in both the control and drop zones (Fig. 3C).
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the control zone, the time-course of MaPG2 mRNA accumulation increased during ripening from day 1 to day 4 after ripening induction and decreased thereafter.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: A similar pattern was observed for MaPG2 in the drop zone, except for a marked but transient decrease (2-fold) observed at day 2 after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The mRNA level of the MaPG3 gene decreased during ripening in the same manner in both the control and drop zones until day 6 after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In overripe fruit taken at day 7, this level was approximately 10-fold higher in the control zone than in the drop zone.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: However, this level remained comparable to that of green fruit sampled at harvest.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Finally, concerning MaPG4, the corresponding transcript was drastically induced in the control zone during the late ripening stages, namely 5, 6, and 7 d after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the drop zone, two peaks of MaPG4 mRNA accumulation were observed.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: The first one occurred 1 d after ripening induction, with approximately 400-fold more expression in the drop zone than in the control zone, and the second one, during the late ripening stage, began at day 5 after ripening induction and reached its maximum at day 7, but at a 2-fold lower level than in the control zone.
body_text.section: Expression of pectolytic genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In addition to the two XET genes, namely MaXET1 and MaXET2, previously isolated from banana fruit (Lu et al., 2004), seven other cDNA sequences were isolated in this study.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In accordance with the nomenclature proposed by Rose et al. (2002), these cDNAs were named MaXTH3 to MaXTH9.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Specific primers designed within the 3#-UTR regions of each XET and XTH genes were used to examine the corresponding gene expression throughout qPCR analysis.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Figure 4 shows the expression pattern in the drop and control zones of the nine XTH genes during banana fruit ripening.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Except for MaXTH4, all other XTHs examined in this study were induced at different magnitudes in banana peel tissue, in the control and drop zones.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the control zone, MaXET1 mRNA was transiently induced during ripening with maximum expression observed 4 d after ripening induction; in line with previous Northern blot data reported in banana (Lu et al., 2004).
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Four XTH genes (MaXET1, MaXTH6, MaXTH8, and MaXTH9) were highly induced at the transcriptional level in the drop zone as compared to the control zone.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: However, this induction was transient, with a maximum of mRNA accumulation observed 3-4 d after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaXTH9 was the most highly and transiently expressed as compared to the four others, while MaXTH8 expression decreased slowly during the late ripening stage.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: By contrast, two XTH genes (MaXTH3 and MaXTH5) were more highly and differentially expressed in the control zone than in the drop zone.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaXTH3 was transiently induced in the control zone with a maximum observed 3 d after ripening induction, while in the drop zone no marked change was observed during postharvest ripening.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: MaXTH5 was less expressed in the drop zone compared to the control zone.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In this area, MaXTH5 presented two peaks of expression at days 3 and 7 after ripening, respectively.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the control zone, MaXET2 and MaXTH7 mRNA accumulation peaked twice at days 2 and 7, and at days 2 and 4 after ripening induction, respectively.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the drop zone, a high mRNA accumulation of MaXET2 and MaXTH7 genes was transient at days 4 and 3 after ripening induction, respectively.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: At this ripening stage, both genes were highly expressed in the drop zone compared to the control.
body_text.section: Expression of MaXTH genes in peel tissues from control and drop zones during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Based on five sequences of expansin genes already isolated from banana fruit (Trivedi and Nath, 2004;Sane et al., 2007), specific primers were designed from the corresponding 3#-UTR regions and used to examine expansin gene expression in both the control and drop zones (Fig.  5).
body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Except for MaEXP3, from which there was a failure to get a single PCR product, the four other expansin genes were differentially expressed in control and drop zone tissues.

body_text.text: By contrast with those of MaEXP2, mRNAs of MaEXP1, MaEXP4, and MaEXP5 accumulated to a greater extent in the drop zone than in the control zone.

body_text.text: Then this level slightly decreased at days 5 and 6, before increasing (2fold) at day 7 after ripening induction.

body_text.text: Compared to the pattern in the control zone, MaEXP2 was on average 1.3-20-fold less expressed in the drop zone during post-harvest ripening, except at day 6 where this expression was comparable in the two tissues.

body_text.text: This level decreased at day 2 to reach a level comparable to that of the control zone before increasing transiently, on average 2-fold more, from days 4-6.

body_text.text: At day 7, the MaEXP1 mRNA level had reduced to a level comparable to that of the control zone.
body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: A marked increase in the MaEXP4 mRNA level was observed during the late ripening stages, namely 4, 5, and 6 d after ripening induction before decreasing approximately 3-fold at day 7 after ripening induction.
body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: Compared to the control zone and except at the last ripening stage (day 7), MaEXP4 mRNA accumulated, on average, 2-fold more in the drop zone after ripening, even during the first ripening stages (1-3 d after ripening induction), while this level was constant in the drop zone.
body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the drop zone, MaEXP5 gene expression was transiently induced until day 4 after ripening induction, where it peaked before decreasing during the last three ripening stages.

body_text.text: The same pattern was observed in the control zone, except that

body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: (ii) with a 2-fold increase at the last ripening stage (day 7).

body_text.section: Expression of MaEXP genes in peel tissues from control-and drop zones, during banana fruit ripening

body_text.text: In the work described here, changes in the expression of various CWMGs (cell wall modifying genes) were examined in relationship with the banana finger drop process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This study was primarily aimed at identifying genes whose expression in the drop zone could be linked to the cell wall disassembly and property changes observed during banana ripening and finger drop by Imsabai et al. (2006) and Saengpook et al. (2007).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Current evidence suggests that cellulose disassembly is not a significant contributor to cell wall disassembly during fruit ripening (Fisher and Bennett, 1991;Newman and Redgwell, 2002;Bennett and Labavitch, 2008).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, our molecular studies were focused on pectolytic and hemicellulosic genes and those involved in physical cell wall properties.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Taken together, our data indicated that cell wall changes that occur in the finger drop area involve major cell wall components, including xyloglucan and pectin, and also cell wall physical properties, namely cell wall loosening mediated by expansin.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Overall, major changes in cell wall Fig. 5.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Expression of expansin genes in banana peel tissue from the control and drop zones.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR) was used to analyse the mRNA accumulation of banana expansin genes in peel tissue sampled from the middle area (control zone) and rupture area (drop zone).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The y-axis represents the relative fold difference in mRNA level and was calculated using the 2 -DDCt formula (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001) with actin as reference.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The mRNA fold difference was relative to that of fruit taken at harvest time (Ht) used as calibrator.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Each data point is the mean of values obtained from qPCR reactions performed in triplicate on one cDNA sample.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Each sample was prepared from four fruits originated from three replicate bunches.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Two biological experiments were performed and they gave similar results.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Vertical bars indicate standard deviation (SD).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: When no bar is shown, the SD is smaller than the symbol.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: modifying gene expression occurred 1-4 d after ripening induction, but in a sequential manner.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Firstly, there were changes in the expression of pectolytic and cell wall loosening genes, mainly during days 1-2, followed by those of xyloglucan genes, mainly during days 3-4.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Moreover, within each mechanism, there was also sequential induction of the different genes involved.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The results of a comparative analysis of CWMG expression in drop and control zones allows the selection of candidate genes involved in the finger drop process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Assuming that the activity of CWMGs examined in this study such as PEL or PG are mainly regulated at the transcriptional level in banana (Pathak and Sanwal, 1998;Marin-Rodriguez et al., 2003;Lohani et al., 2004), it is considered that CWMGs expressed more in the drop zone than in the control zone were candidates.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: A positive correlation was obtained between the banana cultivar prone to finger drop and PEL activity (Imsabai et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Both MaPEL1 and MaPEL2, whose mRNA levels increased by 2-fold and 1.6-fold in the drop zone, possibly induced this increased PEL activity in the drop zone.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, both MaPEL1 and MaPEL2 genes could be considered as candidates.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Imsabai et al. (2006) reported that no clear change in PG activity was correlated with the finger drop process, and that PME activity does not account for the breakage of pectin associated with the finger drop process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Despite this, MaPME2 and MaPG4 could also be considered as putative candidates of finger drop based on the marked change in their mRNA accumulation in the drop zone relative to the control zone.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The discrepancy between PG and PME gene expression and activities could be explained by post-transcriptional regulation of the activation of enzyme activity or subcellular localization (targeting cell walls).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is also possible that the PG and PME activities reported by Imsabai et al. (2006) might represent global activities that do not reflect a putative change in the activity of the different PG and PME isoforms.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Note that the PG enzyme activity measured during banana fruit ripening suggested that more than the three identified isoforms might exist in fruit (Pathak and Sanwal, 1998;Pathak et al., 2000).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: For other cell wall components, MaEXP1, MaEXP4, and MaEXP5 genes appeared to be the main candidates involved in cell wall loosening related to finger drop, with MaEXP1 being the main one, while MaXET1, MaXET2, MaXTH6, MaXTH7, MaXTH8, and MaXTH9 appeared to be candidates for xyloglucan metabolism.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: XTH proteins can display two distinct enzymatic activities, including transglycosylase enzymatic (XET) activity leading to xyloglycan chain synthesis or xyloglucan hydrolase activity (XEH) resulting in their degradation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These two activities are not correlated with the protein structure and subsequently with the XTH protein organization (Rose et al., 2002;Fry 2005;Saladié et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: On the other hand, the involvement of cell wall synthesis, including the xyloglucan component, throughout ripening and mainly between mature green and turning stages prior to perceptible softening, have been reported in tomato, i.e. another fleshy fruit like banana (Mitcham et al., 1989(Mitcham et al., , 1991Greve and Labavitch;1991;Huysamer et al., 1997;Rose and Bennett, 1999).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Because the XTH gene expression and phylogenetic data reported in this study do not presume the activity and the function of corresponding proteins, the involvement of both xyloglucan synthesis and degradation mediated by XTH proteins in the finger drop process cannot therefore be excluded.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Cell wall modification that occurs during the ripening process is complex.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Although the data reported here highlight the involvement of the main cell wall modification enzymes, including PG, PEL, XTHs, and EXP, the possibility cannot be overlooked that, other secondary but important enzymes (b-galactosidase or a-L-arabinofuranosidase) or non-enzymatic mechanisms such as cell wall solubilization (Dumville and Fry, 2003;Zhuang et al., 2006Zhuang et al., , 2007 could be involved in the finger drop process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Ethylene production and fruit softening are two main features that characterize the ripening process of climacteric and fleshy fruit like banana.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our data suggested that finger drop could be related to these two processes.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Indeed, finger drop implies transcriptional changes in genes that are also involved in fruit softening.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, some genes seem to be specific to softening (MaXTH5, MaXTH3, and MaEXP2), finger drop (MaPME2, MaEXP1, MaEXP4, and MaEXP5, MaXTH6, MaXTH8, and MaXTH9), or both (MaPG4, MaPEL1, and MaPEL2; MaXET1, MaXET2, and MaXTH7).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Moreover, the two processes seem to be quite distinct in this variety, as shown by the type of genes involved and their sequential induction, with finger drop being the main induced process followed by softening.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Regarding ethylene, our data showed that Cavendish banana fruit developed finger drop mainly during the early stage of fruit ripening (days 1-4), a period corresponding to a burst of ethylene production.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Concomitantly, a high level of transcription of some ripening-and ethylene-dependent genes like MaEXP1 and MaPELs (Pua et al., 2001;Trivedi and Nath, 2004) was also observed.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It would be interesting to examine the relationship between ethylene production during ripening and the finger drop process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Does the specific induction of the banana finger drop process involve, at molecular level, ethylene production and/or require the ethylene transduction pathway or not?
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In conclusion, the data reported here represent a substantial contribution towards understanding the postharvest banana finger drop phenomenon at the molecular level.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: More specifically, the identification of several cell wall-modifying genes with expression profiles related to finger drop provided us with good candidates for functional studies in banana species.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These candidate genes could be useful in molecular breeding schemes for banana improvement using cultivars differing in their proneness to develop finger drop and which are currently being assessed.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Supplementary data can be found at JXB online.
